text: A garish Jose Cuervo ad flashes by on the side of a brigh yellow HUMMER as it drives through frame, pulling CAMERA the mid-summer crush of semi-clad, youthful bodies on mai street Lake Havasu, Arizona. Havasu is an overcrowded blue collar summer paradise at t peak of its three-month-a-year run of prosperity. You can almost smell the sunscreen as heat waves make the crowd o the pavement appear to waver like a mirage in the desert. Main street is a row of tourist trap t-shirt shops, bars coffee shops and cafes. Beyond lies the shimmering expans of the lake itself. CRANE SHOT ENDS as a four wheel drive pick-up pulls into foreground. A sign on the side of the truck reads “Patter Bait and Dive Shop.” A beautiful golden retriever, BAXTER bounds out of the open truck bed, barking merrily. TED PATTERSON and JULIE TUPPER step out of the cab. They’ one of those golden couples who have the ease and confide of two people who are perfect for each other. They are bronzed, athletic, early thirties.

A bell mounted on the front door JINGLES merrily as Julie enters with Baxter bounding close at her heels. The Proprietor, NATE HASKEL, is a pleasant, if forgettable, middle-aged man, idly surfing the web on his laptop. He rises as they enter.
Hi, Ted. Hi, Miss Tupper. Can you believe this heat?
Pretty miserable, but it’s good for business.
(sighs) Not mine. Tourists usually don’t bring pets... and they don’t think much about taking one home. what can I do for you today?
We need a bag of dry food and a couple of those rawhide chews.
You’re a lucky dog, Baxter. Baxter barks in agreement.
(gathers goods) So, the big day’s coming right up, isn’t it? Julie and Ted share a warm glance.
Only three weeks.
You trying to get me nervous, Nate?
Well, some of us wouldn’t mind if you got cold feet. You got the prettiest girl in Havasu.
That’s sweet, Nate.
That’1l be twenty-two thirty-five. (as Ted pays) You know, those Balinese fighting fish should be in next week.
Great.
(skeptical) Balinese fighting fish?
They’re beautiful, hon. wait ‘til you see ‘em.
Sounds like they’1l eat everything else in the tank.
Don’t worry, they come with their own environment.
I heard the Sumatras are more aggressive than the Balinese.
Maybe so, but I wouldn’t recommend them. They’re much more sensitive to the PH balance. There’s a website here somewhere... Nate punches up the website on laptop.
(takes Baxter) You two chat, I’ve got to get back to the dock. Your brother’s the only one minding the store.
That’s trouble. She gives him a quick kiss.
And don’t forget, you’ve got a dive at one o’clock with that dot com guy.
(chuckles) The great white hunter. How could I forget?
Just don’t let him spear you in that cute tush. Julie pinches Ted’s jeans-clad butt.
Hey, easy...
(waves as she exits) Thanks, Nate!
Oh, anytime, Miss Tupper.
Julie. (big smile) Or Mrs. Patterson.
Okay, Mrs. Patterson.

An isolated inlet. This is the remote end of Havasu... breathtaking red rock terrain sculpted by time itself. No much has changed here in ten thousand years... CAMERA BOOMS DOWN to reveal Ted standing waist-deep in th water, wearing a full wet suit and diving gear. MR. CROUS a slightly pudgy yuppie with a tourist’s sunburn waits be Ted as he checks his spear gun.
The grouper like to feed in these inlets this time of day. Remember it’s all about your approach.

Cool. I’m a human shadow. Lead the way. Ted slips on his dive mask, sucks in his mouth piece, and submerges with barely a ripple. Crouse follows with an awkward SPLASH. As they disappear beneath the surface, CAMERA pushes past them to the nearby shore... where an old TIRE SWING is ti off to an oak tree. All is silent and still. Beat. Then the tire slowly begins to swing. At first, almost imperceptibly. Then in a widening arc, as if it hada ghostly rider. The barren branches of the entire tree beg to TREMBLE.
The ground begins to SHAKE. Several fist-sized rocks tumb down the slopes as we hear the growing RUMBLE of an earthquake.
People in the streets react as the tremor hits Havasu. A pitcher of beer SMASHES to the sidewalk at an outdoor caf
Dogs HOWL and parrakeets FLAP in their cages. Nate manage to catch a fish bowl just as it tips off a counter top.

Patterson and Crouse are tossed about beneath the surface a churning backwash of water. The rocky slope at the bottom of the lake SHAKES violentl Then a jagged crack travels up the slope like an inverse lightning bolt... and a_twenty foot rift in the floor of lake cracks open. There is a deafening ROAR of water and both men are viole sucked into the rift... followed by tons of sand and rock

Julie rises to her feet, screw driver in one greasy hand, spark plug in the other. JACOB WYATT is assisting her. He a tough-as-nails ex-longshoreman in his sixties. The boat they’re working on begins BANGING against the do pylons. Julie grips the gunnels to steady herself. Then it’s over as suddenly as it started.
Nate waits a beat, then sets the fish bowl safely back do The parrakeets PEEP angrily, but settle back in their cag
He struggles to orientate himself in pitch darkness. He’s alive... but where?
Ted CLICKS on a flashlight and the beam reveals a dark mo SHADOW whirling straight towards him.
Julie rises as the boat steadies itself. ZACK PATTERSON, Ted’s younger brother, bursts out of the dive shop and crosses to Julie. Zack’s a tattooed twenty-year-old with curious charm about him.
You okay, Julie?
Yeah. Was that an earthquake?
(gets back to work) Hell, that was nothing but a hiccup. I’ve been in an earthquake. MARCUS (20s), Zack’s co-worker, joins them.
Let me guess, that one with Moses, right? When he parted the red sea. Wasn’t Pharaoh after you guys? Jacob is clearly used to Marcus’ dry humor.
As a matter of fact, it was the San Fran quake in ‘89. Little puss like you would have shit his heart straight into his tighty whities.
Zack, is your brother still out on that dive?
Yeah. Wonder if he felt anything... CAMERA PUSHES into a CLOSE UP of Julie as a hint of conce crosses her features.
Try him on the radio, will you?

Images briefly FLASH against the darkness, like the flick of lightning. A RUMBLE of thunder accompanies each image; FLASH #1 - EXT. LAKE - TED’S BOAT - SUNSET Julie frantically inspects Ted’s empty boat, which floats adrift. Zack and Jacob tie their boat off to Ted’s.
Two state owned Fish and Game boats ROAR along the shorel A grim-faced SEARCH TEAM scans the darkness with powerful spot lights. Julie and Zack ride in the back of the lead boat.
FLASH #3 - INT. TED’S CABIN - NIGHT Julie, surrounded by Ted’s family and friends, breaks dow tears. Zack reacts with anger and frustration, SMASHING h glass in the fire place.

TITLES FADE UP - “THREE DAYS LATER” INT. SHERIFF DOBBS’ OFFICE - LATE AFTERNOON A cluttered Fish and Game Department office. SHERIFF JIM DOBBS, late fifties, is a seasoned enforcement veteran; a good man whose simply been at this job too long to believ he’s going to save anybody but himself and his pension. He sits across the desk from Julie Tupper, who has learne believe the same about him.
We’ve had our resources maxed out for days now. I can’t justify it any longer.
You’re calling the search off.
I have no choice. Fourth of July is the busiest weekend of the year. Maybe after the holiday...
Maybe what?! He could still be alive out there.
He certainly could. In fact, I’d bet money on it. But not in Havasu, maybe not even in Arizona.
What are you talking about?
Look, I don’t want to upset you anymore than I have to...
It’s a little late for sensitivity.
Ted Patterson was a better diver than any man on my search team. There’s no way he drowned in Lake Havasu. (beat) The truth is, there’s no evidence that there was any kind of accident at all.
We found his boat adrift!
Which makes it seem pretty damn strange that we haven’t found a body by now. (pauses) Your wedding was supposed to be in two weeks, correct?
What are you getting at?
We have to consider all the possibilities. One of them is that Ted simply left town.
That’s ridiculous!
You want to tell me what’s more likely? Alien abduction?
How do you explain the businessman Ted was diving with...?
We still have no record of this “Mr. Crouse.” None of the hotels had him registered. No one’s turned up to inquire about him.
So, what... you don’t believe me?
I know this is difficult for you.
You’re difficult for me.
(ice cold) We’re done for today, Miss Tupper.

You were done before you even started, weren’t you Sheriff? (rises) I guess I can’t blame you, this is such a busy time of year for you. Must be hard to keep up with all those fishing licenses. Julie storms out and slams the door.
Jacob is waiting for her, standing beside the dive shop p He knows the story from the look on her face.
(enters passenger’s side) Don’t ask.  10.

They’re just glorified park rangers, Julie. Even if Dobbs wanted to help, he couldn’t find his own ass with two hands and a flashlight. Julie slides into the passenger seat, the entire weight o the tragedy on her shoulders.
What do you think happened to him, Jacob?
(shrugs) Anything can happen in the water. Anything. I don’t care if it’s six feet or sixty.
(searches for the words) But Ted was... he was the best.
I know. I taught him. Jacob cranks the engine, reaches under the seat and hands Julie a coffee thermos.
Coffee’s the last thing I need.
It ain’t coffee. As Jacob pulls out, Julie unscrews the cap and sniffs. Th vapors alone makes her eyes water.
Go ahead, it won’t make you feel any worse. Julie thinks it over... then she takes a deep swig.

The pick-up swings out and passes by a traffic jam of incoming tourists. A large red, white and blue banner is strung across main street. It reads “Happy Independence D From Lake Havasu City Council.”  11.
Posters for “Havasu’s Fourth of July Fireworks Extravagan adorn the building. The dock is busy with a variety of college kids and vacationing families.

TAYLOR BILLINGS enters the shop like he owns the place. H a trust fund kid with a rocker ponytail, streaked with be salon highlights. He’s accompanied by REGGIE TRIPP, a frat type with a gym physique, Reggie’s girlfriend, SYDNEY (hot and knows it) her college roomies CAMILLE and J.C. Camille talks on her cell phone as she aimlessly wanders about the shop. The girls are pretty, but there’s something special about quiet one, J.C. Zack notices her right away.
Hi. Can I help you guys?
We want to rent tanks, regulators, the works.
Light gear. Just for a little sport diving.
Great. Are you certified?
I’m a Navy Seal, man.
Really?
Yes, really.
Still gotta know if you’re certified.
(getting irritated) I’m certified, alright?  12.
Then you’ve got a card...?
I got this. Reggie pulls up his sleeve and flexes. There is an impressive Navy Seals tattoo on his bicep.
(in Zack’s face) You can read, right?
C’mon Reggie. Please don’t start.
(to girls) What about you guys? Ever dive before? J.C. Just some snorkeling. But I’d like to learn.
I can take care of them. I’m an instructor too.

(sighs) Right. Look, if they want to dive, they need to get certified. Takes about a week. Maybe you should do it too, y’know. Just to brush up. Taylor intercedes, pulling out a Gucci money clip loaded fifties.
We’re only in town for a couple of days. I’1ll pay double. Like a rush fee.
Can’t do that. Julie enters from the back of the shop, senses trouble ri away .
What’s going on, Zack?  13.
Gear rentals. I got it. It’s okay. Zack sets down a clipboard with a rental form on it.
If you really want to dive, I can take you guys out myself. As long as I accompany you, one quick lesson and you’re good to go.
It’s a scam.
It’s the law. If you don’t like it, that’s okay. There’s lots of other things to do in Havasu.
(eyes Julie) Why don’t you take us out?
Zack’s the best. If you like, we also do tours on our glass bottom boat. Stay dry and see some spectacular underwater life.
That shit’s for tourists.
Come on, Reggie. Don’t be a dick. Let’s go on the dive. Camille finally finishes her phone call.
Screw this, you guys. We can just hangout on the houseboat. J.C. smiles at Zack. Something’s going on between the two them. J.C. No. Let’s try it. It’d be cool. Sydney squeezes Reggie’s arm.
C’mon, baby.  14.
(shrugs) What the hell...
Best time’s early. Like seven a.m.
Gawd. Are you serious? This is supposed to be a vacation.
He’s right. The lake’1l be calm. Good visibility. Good dive will take you ‘til lunch. We supply sandwiches and sodas. Taylor lays down his platinum card.
Can you stock some Coronas?
Only for after the dive. (aside, to Zack) You sure you want to take these guys out? They seem like a handful. Zack glances up at J.C. and catches her looking at him.
It’1l be okay.
If they don’t shape up during the lesson, promise me you’1l1 pull the plug.
You got my word.
The girls and guys walk to their cars.
I can’t believe it. You liked that guy. J.C. No way.  15.
Bullshit. I know you, J.C. J.C. Alright, he was cute. So what?
He’s a loser townie, J.C. And if you start hanging out with one of the locals it makes us all look like sluts.
Two more weeks and we’re back at school. You can wait ‘til then to get revenge on Chad. J.C. I don’t want revenge on Chad.
Of course you do. He dumped you in front of the entire school.

Besides, nothing’s better than revenge sex. That’1ll get Chad jealous and he’1ll want you back. Then you get to have great make-up sex. And after that, you’1l finally be over Chad, so you can be the one to dump him. Perfect, right? J.C. Camille... are you still seeing that therapist?
No. My mom started dating him, so it kinda seemed like I was talking to my dad.
Zack watches J.C. through the dive shop window. MARCUS, Zack’s co-worker, enters lugging a pair of tanks through
See something you like?  16.
I dunno.
They’re Arizona State girls, Zack. They’re all looking for some preppie asshole with a Porsche and a trust fund. That ain’t us.
True.
Any word on your brother? Zack hangs his head.
He’s gonna turn up, Zack. You did everything you could, so...
(cuts him off) Let’s drop it, okay?
Okay, okay... Marcus reaches into his back pocket, pulls out a flyer...
Here. Concentrate on this. It’s for a Fourth of July party.
Club Zanzabar?
I made a deal with Rodriguez to use the Sand Bar. If I turn a profit, I’1l get to do it every Wednesday night. I’m a club promoter now, man.
You can call it what you want. It’s still the Sand Bar. The place’s got fleas.
I got a D.J. out of Vegas. Guy’s smokin’ hot. (MORE)

MARCUS(cont'd) The place will be packed and not with those stuck up college bitches, either. Zack takes a last glance out the window at the girls. The climb into Taylor’s big Mercedes and peel out. Looks like fun and money.

The orange rim of the sun dips beneath the horizon line. The exact moment it’s snuffed out like a candle... nightf The water is calm. Beat. A TURBULENCE begins just beneath the dark surface... doze and dozens of source points swirl about. One split second of activity, then the strange phenomenon over as if it never happened.
Two tourists, a teenage boy and girl, ride along on horseback, passing a joint back and forth.
Let’s stop for awhile. There’s supposed to be an old boathouse a little ways up this trail. The girl giggles and passes the joint back.
Okay, but you have to catch me first! The girl kicks her horse in the flanks and it takes off l a bolt of lightning. The boy wheels around and pursues at full gallop.
Amy!

The girl is a hell of a rider. She rides at a full gallop straight toward the lake, laughing wildly. Youth plus dop and horse power. Always trouble.  18. The horse plunges straight into the lake. KER-SPLASH! Probably feels good on this hot night. The boy reigns his horse in at the shoreline.
Amy, get back here!

Come and get me! wWhat’s wrong, scared of the water? She and the horse are now chugging along in deeper water, following the shoreline. The boy kicks his horse’s flanks but it spooks at the water line, refuses to go in.

Amy has reached the abandoned boathouse. The dilapidated pier is half-submerged in the inlet. An old tire swing ha from a dead tree. The same tire swing where Ted was sucke under. Now we know exactly where we are... and it’s nota good place to be. Amy can hear the boy calling.
She reigns her horse in and pats him on the neck. He stan in the water, up to his shoulders.

What do you think? Should we go back...? The horse WHINNIES deep in its throat. Something is spook him. Amy follows the horse’s fearful gaze. AMY’S P.O.V. - THE WATER The strange DISTURBANCE appears on the moonlit surface. Dozens, maybe hundreds of churning points of contact. But this time they move with purpose, traveling directly at A The entire formation submerges as it races straight at he The horse rears up in panic. Amy tries desperately to rei him in.  19.
No, Stormy!
He hears the horses frantic WHINNY and realizes something deeply wrong. He kicks his horse into a gallop along the rocky shoreline.
Her horse is clambering for a foothold, still up to its shoulders in the water. Amy is fighting to control him wi all her might.
No, Stormy, no! MYSTERY P.O.V. Eerie SONAR VISION scans the horse beneath the surface as struggles to get it’s footing. The P.O.V. picks up speed, rocketing straight at its inte target.
At a full gallop, somehow knowing, fearing just how bad t could be. He hears Amy SCREAM.
The water all around her suddenly ERUPTS with blood and bubbles. The horse BRAYS in agony, thrashing violently against an unseen enemy. It collapses into the churning water, taking Amy with it.
Finally gallops up to Amy’s location. He dismounts and rushes to the edge of the water. But there’s no sign of the horse or Amy.

The horse breaks the surface, it’s a LIVING NIGHTMARE of flesh stripped down to the bone, yet it’s somehow still alive; it’s eyes rolled back in agony. Amy is coughing water, clutching in blind fear to the saddle horn.  20.

She SCREAMS hysterically as her horse is literally torn t pieces beneath her... she tumbles with it, straight back into the deadly broiling water. The boy flies out of the darkness on the tire swing... He grabs Amy around the waist and swings to safety as the ho finally collapses beneath the surface. All this has happened without ever revealing a glimpse of ungodly force that pulled the horse under.
The boy and Amy hit the ground hard as they land on the r shoreline. He scrambles to his feet, holding her tightly.
Amy, are you okay? She does not reply. By the vacant look on her blood- splattered face we realize she may never be okay again.
Amy?! 1!

A beautiful sunlit dawn. Julie detaches the gas line from large, expensive looking houseboat. MRS. TUNNIE, a middle aged woman with oversized accessories (hat, ear rings sunglasses) steps up to the rail.
So sorry to hear about Ted. A terrible tragedy. But he was a real sportsman, wasn’t he? So he liked taking those risks.
(pauses) It’s still kinda tough to talk about.
Oh, I understand. (beat) So, you must be starting to think about moving on by now...  21.
What?
Well, now that Ted is gone aren’t you going back to Vegas?
I’m not from Las Vegas, Mrs. Tunnie. I’m from L.A.
Really? I heard you were a show girl or something.
I was a realtor.
Only danced part time?
(gives up) That’s fifty-six thirty-nine, Mrs. Tunnie.
(pays) . So you’re going to stay in town after all?
Yes, actually, I am. Ted’s dad needs me to run the dock.
Well, tell him my husband will take this old dock off his hands whenever he’s ready to sell.
This dock has been in Ted’s family for years.
That may be so, but you’re not.
Excuse me?
You’re not part of Ted’s family are you? Not really. (MORE)
MRS. TUNNIE(cont'd) And now that Ted’s gone, you won’t ever be. Joe can’t run things anymore with his heart condition. So... Julie finally starts to get steamed.
You know what, Mrs. Tunnie? There’s only one thing I miss.
About what?
Dancing in Vegas. I miss shaking my bare ass for men like your husband.

I knew it! Where there’s smoke, there’s fire. If you’re smart you’11 cut your losses and move on while you can, missy! (calls to captain) We’re done here, Jose. As the houseboat slowly pulls out, Zack steps up beside Julie.
You really danced in Vegas?
Nope. Think I ought to give it a try? (Zack grins) Don’t answer that. Julie secures the gas line. Jacob steps up and takes over for her.
Let me grab that for you, kid.
Thanks, Jacob.
Don’t let that old gas bag get to you. Her and her old man have been trying to get their hands on this pier for twenty years now.  23.
Well, they’1l have to wait another twenty as far as I’m concerned.
That’s my girl.
I’ve got to take out that charter. You need anything?
I’m fine. Just keep it simple with those kids, okay? She tosses Zack the boat keys.
No worries.

The Patterson’s excursion boat, the “Chill Pill” cuts acr the calm waters of Havasu with Marcus at the helm. Taylor Reggie and the girls are lounging on the open deck as Zac helps them prep for the dive. Zack helps J.C. slip on her tank. He adjusts the harness.
Too tight? J.C. No, it’s fine. I didn’t think air could be this heavy.
Once you’re in the water, you won’t even know it’s there. J.C. Hold on a sec. She adjusts a neoprene knee brace.
Bad knee? J.C. Just gotta take care of it. I tore some cartilage swimming.  24.
What kind of swimming? J.C. I compete for Arizona State. I’1ll be fine as long as I don’t push it.
As far as I’m concerned, the whole point of diving is not pushing it. It’s about going with the flow. I think you’re gonna love it. J.C. Why do you?
What? J.C. Love it so much. I can see it in your face when you talk about it.

(adjusts her harness) I dunno. It’s kind of like flying. No, it’s more like... a dream of flying. You’re weightless, gliding through this secret world where all you can hear is your own breathing. And no one else can see what you see. J.C. You must dive alone a lot.
...guess I do. Reggie interrupts, dropping his tank down with a loud CLA

Should be okay. I checked it this morning. Reggie strains to turn the valve.  25.
Well, you didn’t check this. I can’t work with this cheap crap.
Lemme see. Zack turns the valve in the opposite direction Reggie’s b turning it. We instantly hear the HISS of air coming thro the line.

(over intercom) Ladies and gentlemen, this is your captain speaking. Please stow your tray tables in their upright position. We have arrived.
The boat drifts to a stop, revealing a picturesque hidden cove. Red rock walls tower above placid water. Zack slips overboard into waist-deep water.
Okay. wWe’ll stop for a quick lesson and still have plenty of dive time before lunch.
(admires view) »..not bad.

This sucks. Can we try someplace else?  26. J.C. (slips into the water) C’mon, Cami, it’s beautiful. The water’s perfect.
(displays phone) No reception.
You just might have to talk to us in person without A.T. & T. involved. Zack plunks the gear down on shore. J.C. notices somethin J.C. Look at that...

That thing’s like twenty, thirty years old. I don’t want you to fall on your... um. J.C. My ass? Taylor wades up onto shore.
And a fine ass it is. (to Zack) Calm down there, Aqua Boy. You don’t want to pop a stiffy in your speedo.

Havasu doesn’t have the crystal clear waters of the Caribbean, but it does have its own unique beauty. The “atmosphere” of the water carries breathtaking shafts of light that ripple across the perfect bodies of J.C. and h girlfriends as they gracefully descend.

Zack puts the college kids through some of the basics; Flooding their face masks, then learning how to blow them clear without surfacing. “Buddy Breathing,” in which two divers alternate off of o tank. She’s noticed something peculiar a short distance ahead. immediately recognize the RIFT, the deep crevice that swallowed Ted Patterson alive.

Julie walks a few feet down the dock and grabs a pair of binoculars from a tackle box. She scans the water, but is now past the safety railing, perched on the edge of the d JULIE’S P.0.V. - BINOCULARS A water skier, a young girl, is heading toward the patch turbulence.

A tracking shot from in the water as Julie watches. Something is watching her. There is a growing sense of dr about what lies in wait for Julie. The girl does not surface for one, two, three seconds... empty skis pop up.
Julie slips, losing her balance.
Shoots out of nowhere, grabbing Julie’s forearm... pullin her back to safety.
It’s Nate, the pet store owner. Julie recovers, still ups by what she’s seen.

(awkward) Oh, sorry! I, uh... you almost fell in. Julie glances back at the scene. The ski girl finally surfaces, laughing. Her friends in the boat pick her up. All is perfectly normal.
I just thought I better stop by and service the aquarium. I figure since Ted’s... well, since he’s not around, I...
